text: John Irving may be America's modern-day
Charles Dickens the author of huge
sprawling bestsellers like the world
according to GARP The Cider House Rules
and a widow for one year he came into
the building recently to talk about his
new novel and his unusual and
old-fashioned approach to writing
fiction John Irving you're one of
America's most prolific novelists also
one of the most ambitious your novels
are long and many layered tell us about
the new novel that you've very close to
finished it's your 12th what's it about
what's the story you're telling
it started from me in January 2005 I was
in Vermont on my way north to Rutland to
see my hand doctor a hand surgeon I was
thinking about this novel at the time I
knew there was a cook in a logging camp
in a kind of rough spot in the 1950s
when they were still driving logs down
rivers I knew he'd lost a wife at a
young age and that he was trying to
bring up a twelve-year-old son by
himself there was an old Bob Dylan CD on
my car CD player tangled up in blue must
have heard it a hundred times but a line
a stanza fragment of a stanza sort of
came out at me I had a job in the Great
North Woods working as a cook for sell
but I never did like it all that much
and one day the ask just fell and by the
time I got to my doctor's office I knew
the last sentence of the novel it always
works like that for me I begin with the
last sentence as soon as I got situated
in my doctor's office I was looking
around for something to write the
sentence down with and there was nothing
but a pad of prescription paper on her
desk and so I was writing the last
sentence to myself when she came
to the office and naturally thought I
was writing myself a prescription
painkillers probably that's when that's
happened in January joke you have that
last sentence is that sentence ever get
changed never first sentences they
change all the time sometimes first
chapters become fifth chapters and fifth
chapters become first chapters but last
chapters and last sentences in
particular never have changed not a word
not a comma you know not a parenthesis
it's not a not a - nothing they they
stay fixed like a piece of music that
you are writing toward you so came into
the sort of full existence of this novel
you knew what you're going to do January
2005 it will be published I believe in
November so I'm in late fall 2009 so
that's almost five years was that a
typical length of time or actually it's
short for me it's quickly developing for
me I wrote the first sentence of this
novel seven months after I heard that
last sentence that's fast for me I
usually don't get to the first sentence
in less than a year often more but this
time I got there in seven months from
less and it's the first sentence the
novel's not published yet but can you
give us a treat since you've described
your unusual and original process for
writing a novel just what are the first
and last sentences of this new one sure
because it's the way I do it I should
give you the last sentence first because
it was the first sentence for me it's
the one I was writing toward he felt
that the great adventure of his life was
just beginning as his father must have
felt in the throws and dire
circumstances of his last night in
twisted river that's the last that's the
last sentence it's only the second novel
in which I've been able to work the
title of the novel into the last
sentence that happened in the world
according to GARP more by accident than
in this case which was by design I don't
try too hard to do that I don't force it
but I'm happy when it happens and what's
our first and what's the first sentence
I like it when I can begin the book in
the middle of an accident in the middle
of an action and the first sentence of
this novel is the young Canadian who
could not have been more than 15 had
hesitated too long dr. John Irving
